I.  THE ENSUING PROJECT 
 
1.  The proposed project will undertake a long-term and knowledge-based approach to deliver 
climate adaptive solutions for water resources management. It will modernize outdated irrigation 
and drainage (I&D) subprojects within Amu Darya and (selected reaches of the) Zarafshan River 
Basins in Uzbekistan. The project will increase agricultural water use productivity through a 
threefold  approach:  (i)  climate  resilient  and  modernized  I&D  infrastructure  to  improve 
measurement, control and conveyance within existing systems;1 (ii) enhanced and reliable on-
farm water management including capacity building of water consumers associations, physical 
improvements for land and water management at the farm level and application of high level 
technologies for increased water productivity; and (iii) policy and institutional strengthening for 
sustainable water resources management. This will include strategic support to the Ministry of 
Water Resources (MWR) and its provincial, basin and district agencies, and water consumers 
associations.  
 
2.  The project is estimated to cost $180 million. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) will 
finance $150 million from its ordinary capital resources (concessional loans). The Government of 
Uzbekistan  will  provide  $30  million  through  provision  of  counterpart  staffing,  office  space, 
exemptions of taxes and duties, and interest during implementation. The transaction technical 
assistance and the ensuing loan were included in ADB’s country operations business plan for 
2019–2021.2 
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
3.  The technical assistance (TA) will support the government to prepare subproject feasibility 
studies of representative I&D subprojects to be developed under the ensuing loan. These studies 
will identify proposed interventions and include technical (engineering design) and environmental, 
social and economic and financial assessments.3 A TA grant of $1.2 million will be required to 
prepare the ensuing loan project. It will identify suitable actions for gender inclusiveness in water 
resources management, decision making and income generation. The TA will identify requirements 
for developing a road map for, better strategy, policy and institutional alignment for improved water 
resources management (from the river basin to on-farm) including opportunities for introducing 
technologies. It will also highlight areas for capacity building support in technical, procurement, 
financial management, etc. for relevant project agencies.4 
 
B.  Outputs and Activities 
 
4.  Output 1: Preparation of sector roadmap. This output will support strategic actions for 
water resources management in Uzbekistan, with specific links to investment project activities. It 
will include selected actions for strengthening the policy, legal, and institutional aspects based on

System for a proposed loan to be approved by ADB in 2022 for a tentative amount of $150 million. 
2  Reflected in ADB country operations business plan for Uzbekistan, 2019–2021. 
3  The TA will prepare detailed designs for main elements of I&D systems which will be sufficient for preparation of bid 
documents and cost estimation to within a +/- 10% range. Additional designs and drawings for remaining structures 
would be prepared by implementation/ supervision consultancy. For detailed designs, topographic survey is required 
for channels (irrigation and drainage), embankments and structures. For land surface, the TA will procure and use 
digital terrain modelling (e.g. 1-meter resolution imagery) that should be sufficiently accurate. 
4  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 18 June 2019.

2 
the application of the Australia-developed WaterGuide framework.5 The output will develop: (i) 
asset  management  and  improved  operation  and  maintenance  actions,  (ii)  institutional 
strengthening for river basin planning, and (iii) improvements in water resources measurement 
and management in selected sub-basins (and/or I&D systems) of the Amu Darya river basin. It 
will also prepare a pilot for volumetric measurement of irrigation water supplies, pricing and cost 
recovery mechanisms on a suitable representative subproject. The output will complement the 
Government of Uzbekistan’s request to ADB to support development of its water resources 
strategy to 2030.  
 
5.  Output 2: Preparation of investment project. This output will apply the prior agreed 
selection criteria to prepare a shortlist of future investment subprojects which will be developed 
during loan implementation. It will develop (at least two) representative subprojects to feasibility 
stage. This will include: (i) topographic and geotechnical surveys; (ii) socio-economic baseline 
survey of sample communities (of representative subprojects); (iii) feasibility-stage engineering 
design for representative subprojects; (iv) development of relevant on-farm interventions including 
design and implementation methodology; (iv) undertake economic and financial analysis; (v) 
preparation  of  financial  and  procurement  management  due  diligence  and  action  plan;  (vi) 
preparation of project safeguards in line with ADB and government requirements; (vii) preparation 
of sector assessment and development coordination report; (viii) preparation of project cost 
estimate,  financing  plan,  risk  assessment  and  management  plan,  gender  action  plan, 
procurement plan, implementation schedule, implementation arrangements including role of 
MWR and other stakeholders, and design and monitoring framework including target and baseline 
indicators  and  data  sources;  (ix)  preparation  of  technical  specifications  and  draft  bidding 
documents  for  first  procurement  package;  and  (x)  draft  documentation  for  ADB  Board 
consideration and feasibility design report for internal government project approval as required.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
6.  The TA is estimated to cost $1.2 million and will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-6). The key expenditure items are in Appendix 1.6 
 
7.  The government will provide counterpart support in the form of relevant counterpart staff, 
office accommodation, office supplies, secretarial assistance and other in-kind contributions. The 
government was informed that approval of the TA does not commit ADB to finance any ensuing 
project. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
8.  ADB will administer the TA. It will include specialist support for preparation of representative 
subproject feasibility studies including technical (including procurement), environmental, social and 
economic and financial assessments and proposed interventions. The TA will identify suitable 
actions for gender inclusiveness in water resources management, decision making, and income 
generation. It will also be designed to identify requirements for strategy and policy, legal and 
institutional road development for improved transboundary water resources management including 
opportunities for introducing technologies. The TA will highlight areas for capacity building support 
in technical, procurement, financial management, etc. for relevant project agencies. ADB’s Central

Security  for  the  efficient  preparation  of  the  loan  project  and  facilitation  of  its  approval  by 
government agencies.
